reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central move in the essay: inferring that mostly-great futures are unlikely “by default” because the eutopian target is “narrow,” supported by product-of-factors and “many ways to be wrong” reasoning. If that inference is undercut by showing that dynamics/attractors could make high-value basins large, the paper’s case for low default flourishing probability is materially weakened (though not fully, because the essay also argues from population ethics, bounded/unbounded value functions, fat tails, etc., which don’t rely purely on geometric uniform-sampling intuitions). Strength is moderate: the critique correctly notes that “narrowness” is measure- and dynamics-dependent and that the paper doesn’t explicitly model basins of attraction; this is a real gap for claims about default probabilities. However it overstates by implying the argument “quietly assumes Euclidean geometry” and “uniformly sampled noise”: the paper does provide non-geometric structure (multiplicative toy model, historical moral error examples, and technical arguments about value functions and resource scaling). Those may still be disputable, but they are more than a bare metaphor. Correctness is fairly high but not perfect for those overstatements. Clarity is good: it’s understandable and points to a concrete missing link (from many issues to tiny probability without a model of attractors). Dead weight is low, and it stays on a single issue. Overall, it’s a thoughtful objection that meaningfully pressures one pillar of the argument but doesn’t decisively refute the overall position.
title: The narrow target metaphor ignores attractor dynamics in moral space
